conversation.content: [surprised] Miranda? After three years, you just walk into my greenhouse looking for ghost orchids? [quietly] The rarest flowers we cultivate, and coincidentally the most expensive ones we have.
[overly polite] Hello, James. [warmly] The place looks incredible, you've really transformed it since your uncle left it to you. I need twelve ghost orchids for tomorrow, money's no object.
[sarcastically] Money's no object now? That's quite a change from when you left me for that pharmaceutical executive because I was just a gardener with dirty fingernails and no trust fund.

[defensive] That's not fair, we wanted different things. [quickly] Look, this isn't personal, it's for Richard Castellano's seventieth birthday, and his new wife specifically requested these orchids from your greenhouse.
[perceptive] Richard Castellano, the hotel mogul with terminal cancer and no children? [chuckles] How remarkably convenient that you're suddenly passionate about rare orchids for his special day.
I care about Richard deeply, and making his birthday perfect matters to me. [sighs] Can we please just handle this as a business transaction without dissecting my motivations?
[firmly] Ghost orchids take seven years to bloom, and each one represents hundreds of hours of careful cultivation. [pause] They're not accessories for whatever game you're playing with a dying man.
[frustrated] You think you know everything about me, but people change. [passionately] Maybe I actually found someone who appreciates me for more than just being arm candy at faculty dinners.
[bitter] Right, because a seventy-year-old billionaire definitely sees your inner beauty. [quietly] The Miranda I loved wouldn't have needed his money to feel appreciated or valuable.
[shaky voice] The Miranda you loved was broke, desperate, and tired of pretending that love could pay rent. [very quietly] Sometimes survival looks ugly from the outside, James.
[empathetically] I would have given you everything I had, which I know wasn't much, but it was real. [exhales] These orchids bloom once and die, just like whatever you're building with him.
[defensive] Spare me the metaphors.

[calmly] I'll sell you six orchids, not twelve, because that's all I can spare without destroying the breeding program. [firmly] But you have to plant one yourself, get your hands dirty again, remember who you used to be.
[hesitantly] That's blackmail, making me perform for flowers like I'm still that girl who used to help you with the seedlings at dawn before my second job at the diner.

[warmly] That girl understood that beautiful things require patience and care, not shortcuts. [sighs] She knew the difference between cultivation and exploitation, even when she was exhausted and broke.
[angry] Easy to romanticize poverty when you inherited this place free and clear! [loudly] You never had to choose between electricity and groceries, or smile while someone gropes you for tips!
[regretful] You're right, I had advantages you didn't, and I never really understood how hard it was. [very quietly] But using someone's death as your payday isn't the answer, Miranda.
[crying while speaking] He's kind to me.

[gently] I know you want to believe that, but kindness doesn't come with prenups and private investigators. [pause] Take the orchids, but promise me when this ends, you'll remember you deserve real love.
[bitter] Real love doesn't keep you warm when the heat gets shut off. [whispers] But thank you for the orchids, they'll make him happy for whatever time he has left.

scenario: A gold digger seeking rare orchids for a wealthy mark's birthday discovers their ex-lover now manages the only greenhouse that cultivates them.
